newsitem.title: USA: US Rep Saxton says BLS unfairly criticized on CPI.
newsitem.headline: US Rep Saxton says BLS unfairly criticized on CPI.

text.p: Rep. Jim Saxton, chairman of the congressional Joint Economic Committee, said Tuesday the Bureau of Labor Statistics was unfairly criticized for not acting quicker on revising the consumer price index (CPI).
Saxton, a New Jersey Republican, blamed the White House for not including a request for funding the CPI revision in its fiscal 1994 budget submitted in 1993.
"It wasn't because of BLS fumbling, but rather because the White House had dropped the ball and blocked the agency's budget request for a CPI revision," he said in a statement.
Congress would also have had to play a part in approving such a funding request if it were made.

A JEC spokeswoman pointed to a paragraph of a letter Saxton received from BLS Commissioner Katharine Abraham in response to a question at a March 7 hearing about the history of decisions on funding for the CPI revision.

"The BLS had developed plans for a possible start to the Revision in Fiscal Year 1994, but it ultimately was decided not to proceed with a request to the Congress for funds to start this work until the following year," Abraham wrote.

The CPI became a political issue this year after an advisory commission headed by economist Michael Boskin reported last December that the CPI overstated cost of living by about 1.1 percentage points a year.

Since increases in some federal benefits such as Social Security are tied to the CPI, reducing any overstatement could mean lower increases in those benefits, which could be a politically sensitive move. But money the government would save could make balancing the budget easier.
